title: 106_hr3203
content: The "Broadcast Ownership for the 21st Century Act" may be cited as the short title. It includes cross-ownership limitations. The Federal Communications Commission will modify regulations to remove restrictions on granting or renewing broadcast station licenses based on newspaper ownership. The Communications Act of 1934 is amended to allow ownership of broadcasting stations and cable systems in the same community. The Federal Communications Commission will revise regulations to allow television broadcast stations to affiliate with multiple networks, with a deadline for completing necessary actions. The Federal Communications Commission will revise regulations to allow television broadcast stations to affiliate with multiple networks, with a deadline of 90 days for completing necessary actions. SEC. 3 amends the Communications Act of 1934 to limit UHF television stations to 50% of television households in their market for national audience reach calculations. SEC. 4 limits the authority of the Federal Communications Commission. SEC. 4 amends the Telecommunications Act of 1996 to increase the ownership limit from 35% to 45%. The Federal Communications Commission must implement this change within 90 days. The Communications Act of 1934 is amended to restrict foreign ownership of broadcast or common carrier licenses. No licenses shall be granted to aliens, foreign corporations, or corporations with significant foreign ownership. The Communications Act of 1934 is amended to restrict foreign ownership of broadcast or common carrier licenses. Licenses will not be granted to corporations with significant foreign ownership if it is deemed against the public interest. Foreign countries that allow broadcast station licenses to be held by aliens or foreign governments may receive reciprocal treatment. The Communications Act of 1934 is amended to restrict foreign ownership of broadcast or common carrier licenses. Licenses will not be granted to corporations with significant foreign ownership if it is deemed against the public interest. The Commission may allow foreign entities to own a portion of the capital stock of a corporation holding a broadcast station license in a foreign country. Licenses will not be granted to corporations with significant foreign ownership if it is deemed against the public interest. The Commission may allow foreign entities to own a portion of the capital stock of a corporation holding a broadcast station license in a foreign country, with a voting stock limit of 40 percent for United States persons.
